awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Nurturing Science Identity through Culturally Relevant Organic Chemistry Laboratories
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. This project at Spelman College will transform the organic lab curriculum by providing a learning experience that fosters science identity in black women. This curriculum will provide guided inquiry experiments supplemented by culturally relevant activities and instructional materials to engage, motivate, and improve student outcomes related to identity development processes and academic performance. 

The overall goal of this project is to improve the academic performance of students while simultaneously empowering and affirming their role as scientists. The specific aims are to: 1) revise the first semester organic chemistry laboratory by developing and implementing guided inquiry modules that contain culturally relevant instructional materials, 2) characterize the impact of the modules on students beliefs about science, beliefs about their role as a scientist, their motivation to study chemistry, and their mastery of experimental techniques and concepts and 3) assess the implementation of the modules based on faculty and student feedback. The modules will be developed by a faculty working group consisting of organic chemistry and social science faculty. This project will impact over 350 students from Spelman College and the materials developed from the project will allow for adaptation beyond Spelman. The findings from this work will contribute to the understanding of diversity initiatives in STEM and serve as an inclusive curricular model to prepare women and minorities that go on to graduate school or the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Objectives, Outcomes, and Impact

1. The first goal of the project was to revise the organic I chemistry laboratory by developing and implementing new inquiry-based modules that are complemented by culturally relevant activities. This goal was completed by revising the lab curriculum to include 7 new or revised inquiry-based experiments. To accompany these experiments, 4 culturally relevant activities were created that acknowledged the cultural norms among our students, acknowledged the ability of students to create knowledge and contribute knowledge from their experiences, and acknowledged the importance of addressing real problems related to chemistry. The culturally relevant activities also allowed students to reflect on chemistry in their personal lives and how chemistry impacts them socially and politically.

2. The second goal was to characterize the impact of the developed modules on students': (a) Beliefs about the role of science in addressing social and cultural issues; (b) Beliefs about their role in the scientific paradigm; (c) Motivation to study chemistry; and (d) Mastery of experimental techniques an concepts. Overall, students responded favorably to the course content and demonstrated an increase in science awareness, identity, and self-efficacy from year to year. Throughout data collection, participants also reported an increase in their belief in their capacity to master chemistry knowledge and skills and use strategies to learn chemistry well. Participants' self-efficacy (belief in their ability) to master chemistry knowledge showed consistent increases from pre- to post-assessment over the course of the grant. These factors have been demonstrated to play an integral role in STEM retention, persistence, and career choice.

3. The third goal was to assess the success of implementation based on peer and faculty observations and students' attitudes toward the revisions. Overall, students' attitudes about course revisions indicate a positive perception of the implementation. They thought the instructional materials were easy to follow and provided sufficient information to complete the assignments or experiments. Following their experience with the modules, participants in the post-assessments were more likely to perceive that chemistry is interesting, relevant to their lives, and the concepts from the course were relevant to the real world. Similarly, participants' beliefs that they could use chemistry strategies well increased over all three years of implementation. Qualitative interviews from two undergraduate teaching assistants who completed the revised lab before working as teaching assistants noted that their perspectives on chemistry evolved after taking the course. The teaching assistants reported being more confident and wanting to include social justice in their work in STEM and the cultural aspects of STEM after engaging in culturally relevant modules. Faculty also enjoy teaching the new inquiry-based experiments and culturally relevant modules and are working to revise the organic II laboratories so that both laboratories are current and focused towards real world problems involving chemistry.

4.Supplemental funding was also granted to adjust for remote laboratories during the COVID-19 pandemic. The entire curriculum was taught online for a semester and a half, thus online modules were developed and students received chemistry kits at home to perform some experiments. Lab reports and assignments were collected digitally via Canvas, TurnitIn, and Gradescope in this transition and test banks were created to give quizzes online. After the transition back to face-to- face teaching, many of the digital aspects related to submission and grading were retained in the course to benefit students and instructors.   

Impact: This work has an impact on both the teaching of chemistry and the learning experience. It allows for students to inform the teaching based on their backgrounds, experiences, and interests and it serves to incorporate those things into the course. Thus, the teaching experience is shifted in some instances from the instructor to the students and the real-world knowledge that students have is put on display. The culturally relevant modules are also interdisciplinary so this work serves as a model in chemistry as well as other disciplines. Finally, the project intentionally provides ways for students to communicate with their families and friends about the work they are doing in chemistry. This takes the work out of the academic sphere and puts science into communities, homes, and conversations. The findings from this work will contribute to the understanding of diversity initiatives in STEM and serve as an inclusive curricular model to prepare women and minorities who go on to graduate school or the STEM workforce.

Additional Products: Shanina Sanders Johnson, Addressing the melanin in the room: Culturally relevant teaching benefits science and students. Chemistry World, 2023, 20 (2), 5.

Jalyn White and Aliyah Webster, The Spelman Difference: Teaching that shows we belong in science. Chemistry World, 2023, 20 (2), 64.
